awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Sustainable Urine Processes through integration of Education and Research (SUPER)
awd_abstract_narration:
1150790-Boyer
Urine separation and treatment has the potential to radically transform wastewater management whereby water, nutrients, and energy are recovered and toxic contaminants are sequestered.  Despite the potential of urine separation and treatment, it has not been widely implemented because of an absence of engineering strategies that are efficient in contaminant removal, practical to implement, and acceptable to society. Accordingly, the research objective of this project is to generate new knowledge of physicochemical processes in urine to achieve sustainable urine separation, treatment, and resource recovery. The central research hypothesis is that ion exchange is a robust, selective, and scalable process, and as such, can be used as a foundational strategy for urine treatment. The education objective of this project is to generate excitement and better understanding of wastewater management ? a topic that is largely underappreciated by society due to the ?ick? factor. The central education hypotheses are that water conservation and visual iconic symbols can be used to increase appreciation, improve understanding, and facilitate learning of STEM concepts related to wastewater management. The research and education objectives will be accomplished by pursuing four specific aims: (1) identify ion exchange processes in urine that achieve maximum and selective recovery of nutrients; (2) quantify the efficacy of ion exchange removal of pharmaceuticals from urine in terms of both removal efficiency and toxicity; (3) identify the life cycle impacts of treatment strategies used to recover nutrients and remove pharmaceuticals from source-separated urine; and (4) evaluate innovative learning approaches for generating excitement and improving understanding of wastewater management. The approach will be to systematically evaluate the kinetics, thermodynamics, and toxicity of ion exchange processes in urine through laboratory experiments; formulate a mathematical model that couples microscale ion exchange with macroscale reactor engineering; conduct life cycle impact assessment of urine treatment; develop an educational pilot program with the Florida Park Service; work with middle school science teachers; and mentor undergraduates and graduates in research.  The proposed research is expected to generate new knowledge of physicochemical processes in urine and identify ion exchange strategies that recover nutrients, decrease toxicity, and lead to a sustainable life cycle. The project will establish a new partnership with the UF Center for Precollegiate Education and Training (CPET). The CPET partnership will promote teaching, training, and learning through undergraduate and graduate students hosting workshops for middle school science teachers who will bring their new knowledge back to their students. The educational activities are expected to impact children, students, and adults thereby generating excitement and new understanding of wastewater management.

por.por_cntn:
The research goal of this project was to generate new knowledge of physical-chemical processes in urine to achieve sustainable urine separation, treatment, and resource recovery. The research goal had three specific research objectives: (1) identify ion exchange processes in urine that achieve maximum and selective recovery of nutrients; (2) quantify the efficacy of ion exchange removal of pharmaceuticals from urine in terms of both removal efficiency and toxicity reduction; and (3) identify the life cycle impacts of treatment strategies used to recover nutrients and remove pharmaceuticals from source-separated urine. 


As background, human urine accounts for approximately 1% of domestic wastewater by volume but contributes a disproportionate mass load to wastewater—greater than 80% nitrogen (N), 50% phosphorus (P), and 60% pharmaceuticals. The basis for urine diversion is that nutrient recovery from urine targets valuable chemicals where they are present at a concentration much higher than present in comingled wastewater. Thus, the recovery processes are applied only to the small volume of urine, thereby requiring less materials and energy. The separate collection of undiluted urine creates greater opportunities for recycling nutrients to agriculture than in conventional wastewater systems. Furthermore, the remaining wastewater can be treated at a centralized facility using simpler processes and less energy because the wastewater is depleted in nutrients, which in turn reduces nutrient discharges. Collecting undiluted urine conserves potable water by using water-free and low-flush fixtures, which generates less wastewater and thereby extends the lifetime of existing drinking water and wastewater infrastructure. Finally, urine diversion makes it is possible to decrease the toxicity of wastewater effluent by eliminating the micropollutants excreted in urine and obviate the need to upgrade wastewater treatment plants with energy-intensive processes for micropollutant removal.  


The results of this project show that there are real opportunities for urine diversion from nutrient removal and recovery, potable water savings, and pharmaceutical sequestration and toxicity reduction. Early on, urine diversion was viewed as a product—something that one could insert in a urinal or install in a building to recover nutrients for example—but through this project came to realize that urine diversion is best conceptualized as a process. The urine diversion process includes the obvious components like non-water urinals, urine-diverting toilets, urine piping, and storage tanks, but it also includes people, drinking water and wastewater systems, and components further afield including receiving waters, fertilizer production, and agriculture operations. As such, the benefits of urine diversion are derived from extension of the system boundary to include drinking water production, wastewater treatment, fertilizer production, and aquatic ecotoxicity potential. The implementation of urine diversion is likely to take the form of a distributed system that includes a blend of decentralized (i.e., building scale) and centralized (i.e., city scale) treatment. Finally, a urine diversion system must consider human behavior and interactions with people.


Specific outcomes from this project include new knowledge on urine treatment and design of urine diversion systems including ability to recover nutrient from urine by ion exchange, ability to selectively remove pharmaceuticals from urine by ion exchange, and identification of environmental costs and benefits of implementing ion exchange at the community scale. This project contributed to 25 journal publications, and supervising 6 PhD students, 4 MS thesis students, and 7 undergraduate thesis students. Hence, this project contributed to advancing knowledge within Environmental Engineering and across fields, and supported the training and development of students in brining sustainable engineering solutions to pressing societal problems.
